summary: Republicans should insist on using the $429 billion in Fed funds.. title: John Kerry's Arab Peace
summary: Learning from the former secretary of State's words of four years ago.. Speaking at the Brookings Institution, Mr. Kerry, then Secretary of State, insisted that Palestinian peace was a precondition for Israel to make peace with its Arab neighbors.

title: The Silence of Pope Francis

Thus did a man who started the week a Hong Kong billionaire end it a Chinese dissident.

title: 'The Great Demographic Reversal' Review: The Perils of Aging
summary: As workers become fewer in number and global wages rise, we may see less inequality but more inflation and higher interest rates.. Mountains are thrown up by colliding tectonic plates, but the forces at work in their creation are hidden from view and were, for a time, ill-understood. In advanced societies in recent decades, we have seen striking changes in work, investment and income distribution, yet central bankers and ministers of finance, among others, have failed to grasp the underlying forces that brought them about. In "The Great Demographic Reversal," Charles Goodhart and Manoj Pradhan, both Britain-based economists, vividly document past demographic changes, along with their broad effects, and outline the strikingly different changes that, in their view, are soon to come. Not only is their book well argued, but it is bold as well. It defies the conventional wisdom that inflation will not be a problem in the near future.

title: Companies Face New Pressures to Diversify Boards. It's Sensitive.

summary: Most Popular News. title: GM Sees the Future and It Is an Electric One
summary: The socialization of the U.S. automobile market is intensifying. First to California, which already has environmental policies that often lead to darkness and blackouts, but now with GM's help the state will have more leverage in dictating the automobile market for the entire country. title: Shutdowns Can Sometimes Bring Out the Best in Us
summary: Being stuck at home has forced me to go on a life diet-to learn what's important and to shed the rest of my life's baggage.. In response to "In a Stay-at-Home Pandemic, Sportswriter Finds a Silver Lining" (Sports, Nov. 27): I had the opportunity just before Thanksgiving to work side by side with a new pastor of social justice at the church I attend. We were co-leading activities to collect, pack and distribute ingredients for 425 families' Thanksgiving dinner. When all the other volunteers had left and she and I were in the room alone, she looked at me and confessed, "I feel guilty, but this has been a good year for me. Being stuck at home has forced me to go on a life diet-to learn what's important and to shed the rest of my life's baggage."

title: No Need to Worry About Santa Claus and Covid-19
summary: I was quite distressed to read about the worries children are experiencing about Santa Claus possibly contracting Covid-19.. I was quite distressed to read about the worries children are experiencing about Santa Claus possibly contracting Covid-19 ("Dear Santa, Be Sure to Wear a Mask. The Reindeer Too," Page One, Nov. 28). Santa is a magical being and, therefore, is immune to Covid. And since Covid cannot live in Santa, he cannot spread Covid. This is a simple, scientific fact. Kids, don't worry about Santa. He will be fine.

Kelsey Silverstein, 28, and Mark Donoher, 30, resold a Sea Turtle-patterned Snap-T fleece from 1996 for $165 about a year and a half ago. Today that same fleece could fetch more than $300 online. Rather than worry that they sold it too soon, the couple-who run Orbital Outdoors, an online clothing store dedicated to vintage outdoor gear-is looking ahead. "I'm hoarding the best stuff," said Mr. Donoher who is convinced the market can only go up. "I think everything right now is just beginning."

WASHINGTON-Lawmakers expect to pass a one-week spending bill soon that would keep the government funded through Dec. 18 and buy more time for complex, year-end negotiations on a long-term funding measure and coronavirus relief.

title: Fight for Upstate New York House Race Continues in Court
summary: Republican Claudia Tenney holds razor-thin tentative lead over U.S. Rep. Anthony Brindisi. The rematch between Republican Claudia Tenney and U.S. Rep. Anthony Brindisi will slog on in a central New York courtroom this week as the Democratic incumbent urges a judge to open more ballots, while Ms. Tenney asks to be certified as the winner-by 12 votes.
